AI Tools

Last updated August 29, 2025.

This is not an exhaustive list of AI tools. These tools change frequently, and the pricing and access info below may be out of date. Unless otherwise indicated, the University and Law School do not provide licenses for students or faculty. Most tools have a free trial or have a freemium pricing model where you can get limited access for free. Please reach out to nick.hafen@law.byu.edu with questions or updates.

General AI Tools

Please review the University's genAI website for updated information on approval and access for various genAI tools as well as guidelines on entering sensitive or restricted information: https://genai.byu.edu/resources/

  Faculty Access Student Access Free/Personal Tier
OpenAI ChatGPT

Faculty and staff can request here.

 Students can get 2 months of free access to ChatGPT Plus (available through May 31, 2025). Yes
Microsoft Copilot (Enterprise) (browser app) Yes. Instructions here. Yes
Microsoft Copilot 365 (integrated in Microsoft apps) Full-time and student employees can request here. No
Zoom AI Assistant Yes, included in your Zoom license for faculty, staff, and students with Zoom licenses. Details here. No
Adobe Firefly See details here. Some features and software are free for students and employees, and others are free for employees and discounted for students. No
Perplexity Sign up with your law school email address for one year of Pro access. Yes
Anthropic Claude Under review.   Yes
Google Gemini To be evaluated.   Yes. Use non-law school account.
Notebook LM (Google) To be evaluated.   Yes. Use non-law school account.
Other AI tools      

 

Legal-Specific Generative AI Tools

The Law Library provides access to a number of specialized legal AI tools. You must follow your instructor's policies and instructions on whether and how to use these tools for coursework.

  Law School Access
LexisNexis Protégé Included in your existing license.
Thomson Reuters CoCounsel Included in your existing license.
vLex Vincent Legal research platform for US and foreign/international law. Contact nick.hafen@law.byu.edu or kristen.kellems@law.byu.edu to set up an account. 
Harvey Faculty, 2Ls, 3Ls, and LLMs have access to Harvey, a workflow tool used by many large law firms. 1Ls will be granted access after attending the Generative AI LTI training or by special request (contact nick.hafen@law.byu.edu).
Paxton AI Legal research platform. Contact nick.hafen@law.byu.edu to set up an account. Please note that all law school users will have access to files uploaded to the Shared Drive.
Luri

Luri's BriefCase tool helps students brief cases to prepare for class. They are also beta testing BlueCite, a citation checker. Sign up with your law school email address for free access through the end of 2025. The company invites feedback and is often willing to grant or extend free access in exchange. Contact nick.hafen@law.byu.edu for more details.

You can also access Luri through the Apple App Store.

Below are some additional AI legal research tools. Legaltech Hub maintains a more comprehensive list of legal AI products.

  • LawDroid Copilot. Free trial.
  • Midpage AI. Free trial. Focused on litigation and research.
  • Blue J. Requires subscription. Focused on tax.
  • Descrybe.ai. Free tier with additional paid features. Focused on case law research.
  • Alexi. Free trial. Focused on research and litigation.

AI Prompting

General

  • Ethan Mollick, AI for Beginners: A Simple Guide to Using AI as a Newbie, Wall Street Journal (May 10, 2024)
  • Google Gemini Prompting Guide 101
  • Anthropic Prompt Library

Legal

  • Jake Nelson, How to Write Effective Legal AI Prompts (March 15, 2024)
  • Daniel B. Schwarcz & Jonathan H. Choi, AI Tools for Lawyers: A Practical Guide (March 29, 2023)
  • Michael D. Murray, Prompt Engineering and Priming in Law (July 29, 2024)
  • AI Law Librarians Blog: AI Prompt Library for Law: Research, Drafting, Teaching, and More
  • Tyler Ebert, Prompt and to the Point: A Guide to Legal Prompt Engineering
  • Dennis Kennedy, A Generative AI Prompting Primer for Law Students, 4–9 (April 30, 2024)
  • Jordan Furlong, The one skill lawyers need to use Generative AI (Nov. 28, 2023)
  • Josh Kubicki, GenAI Prompting Quick Guide, LinkedIn (2023)

Misuse of Generative AI

This database tracks instances of lawyers citing hallucinated cases. Below is a selection of cases.

  • Smith v. Farwell (Mass.), Order Imposing Sanctions
  • Mata v. Avianca Airlines (S.D.N.Y.), NYT article
  • Eugene Volokh, Six Federal Cases of Self-Represented Litigants Citing Fake Cases in Briefs, Likely Because They Used AI Programs, Reason.com (Nov. 13, 2023)
  • Clara Geoghegan, Colorado Lawyer Cited Fake Cases in Motion Written with ChatGPT, LawWeek Colorado (June 21, 2023)
  • Iovino v. MSA Security (W.D. Va.), Memorandum Opinion, 13–15 (blog post summary)
  • Chris Dolmetsch, Lawyers Use ChatGPT to Add Up Fees, Judge Faults Their Math, Bloomberg Law (Feb. 22, 2024)
  • Jessica R. Gunder, Rule 11 Is No Match for Generative AI, 27 Stan. Tech. L. Rev. 308 (2024)
  • Lacey v. State Farm (C.D. Cal.), Order Imposing Sanctions, TheVerge article. Attorneys from law firms Ellis George and K&L Gates submitted a brief with AI-generated (hallucinated) authorities.
  • Ko v. Li (Ontario). Attorney submitted a pleading citing non-existent cases and citing a case that stood for the opposite proposition.
  • Saxena v. Martinez-Hernandez (D. Nev., May 14, 2025), Order Denying Renewed Motion for Reconsideration (ECF No. 124). Plaintiff used generative AI to draft a filing that included a placeholder (“[Your Full Name]”) and cited fabricated cases.
  • Garner v. Kadince (2025 UT App 80) (opinion, video of hearing). Unlicensed law clerk used ChatGPT to draft a petition and included hallucinated cases, and the supervising attorneys failed to verify the citations before filing the petition.

  • Map of Copyright Lawsuits v. AI

Courts

  • IAPP, Global AI Law and Policy
  • National Conference of State Legislatures, AI 2024 Legislation

Keeping up with GenAI

Podcasts are a great way to keep up on what's possible with AI and how it's affecting the legal industry. Here are some suggestions:

Legal tech

  • Legaltech Week (Apple/Spotify) - Weekly; legal tech journalist roundup of stories; can watch live on Fridays 3pm ET on Zoom (registration link).
  • The Geek in Review (Apple/Spotify) - Weekly interview show; often guests from vendors.
  • Scaling Laws (Apple/Spotify) - Twice a week; discussion of AI policy.
  • AI & the Future of Law (Apple/Spotify) - 2-3x/month; discussion of AI in the legal industry.

Tech

  • Vergecast (Apple/Spotify) - Twice a week; covers tech generally.
  • AI Applied (Apple/Spotify) - Short episodes (10-15 min.) a few times a week; covers AI developments generally.
